problems.title: Irreducibility of the polynomial x^3 + 2x + 1 in Z_3[x]
problems.hint: • Show that it does not have a root in $\mathbb{Z} _3$.
problems.solution: Since the polynomial is of degree $3$, it is enough to show that it does not have a root in $\mathbb{Z} _3$. Let $p(x) = x^3 + 2x + 1.$ The possible roots are $\bar{0} , \bar{1} , \bar{2} .$ Note that \begin{align*} p(\bar{0} ) & = 1 \equiv 1 \ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3)\\ p(\bar{1} ) & = 4 \equiv 1 \ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3)\\ p(\bar{2} ) & = 13 \equiv 1\ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3). \end{align*} Thus, the polynomial is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z} _3$.

problems.title: The minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over Q
problems.problem: Find the minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over $\mathbb{Q} $.
problems.hint:
• Assume $x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5}$, and power $x$ to get rid of $\sqrt{3} \text{ and } \sqrt{5} $. This will give a polynomial satisfying $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} .$
  • Now show that the polynomial is minimal.
problems.solution:
To find the minimal polynomial of $x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over $\mathbb{Q} $, observe that \begin{align*} x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} & \implies x^2 = 8 + 2 \sqrt{15} \\ & \implies (x^2 -8)^2 = (2 \sqrt{15} )^2 \\ & \implies x^4 - 16x^2 + 64 = 60 \\ & \implies x^4 - 16x^2 + 4 = 0. \end{align*}
It is clear that the polynomial $p(x) = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4$ satisfies $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $. We only need to check that it is minimal which is equivalent to show that the polynomial is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q} $. By the rational root theorem, the possible rational roots for the polynomial $p(x)$ are $\pm 1, \pm 2$ and $\pm 4$. But, none of these satisfies $p(x)$ and $p(x)$ does not have a root in $\mathbb{Q} $.
Let us assume that $p(x)$ is reducible over $\mathbb{Q} $, that is, it can be broken into monic quadratic polynomials in $\mathbb{Q} $, say \begin{align*} & (x^2 + a x + b)(x^2 + c x + d) = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4 \\ \implies & x^4 + (a + c)x^3 + (ac + b + d)x^2 + (ad + bc) x + bd = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4. \end{align*} Comparing the coefficients, we get \begin{align*} c = -a, \quad b + d - a^2 = - 16, \quad a(d - b) = 0, \quad \text{ and } bd = 4. \end{align*} Consider $a (d - b) = 0$. Note that if $a = 0$, then we have \begin{align*} bd = 4 \text{ and } b + d = -16. \end{align*} Thus, $b$ and $d$ are roots of the quadratic equation $t^2 + 16t + 4 = 0$, which does not have are rational roots (discriminant (which is $240$) is not a square), thus $a = 0$ is not possible.

If $b - d = 0$, that is, $ b = d$, then $b^2 = 4$, so $b = \pm 2$. Also, \begin{align*} b + d - a^2 = -16 & \implies 2b - a^2 = -16 \\ & \implies a^2 = 2b + 16 = \begin{cases} 20, &\text{ if } b = 2 ;\\ 12, &\text{ if } b = -2. \end{cases} \end{align*} In any case, $a$ can not be a rational number and hence $b= d $ is also not possible. Thus, the polynomial is irreducible and hence minimal.
